PdCl2/Bu4NI: An efficient and ligand-free catalyst for the alkoxycarbonylation of organic chlorides Yizhu Lei Rui Zhang Linjuan Wu Qinda Ou Hui Mei Guangxing Li ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Luoyu Road 1037, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, Huazhong University of Science and Technology Luoyu Road 1037 Wuhan Hubei 430074 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 27 87543032; fax: +86 27 87543632. Graphical abstract An active, efficient and ligand-free Pd catalyst system was developed for the alkoxycarbonylation of organic chlorides using PdCl2/Bu4NI catalyst. The influences of various parameters such as solvent, base, ligand and promoter on activity in the alkoxycarbonylation of CH2Cl2 were investigated. Ligand-free PdCl2 with the aid of Bu4NI showed efficient catalytic performance for this inactive transformation, and 87.6% conversion with 67.3% total yield of esters was obtained using 2.5mol% PdCl2 at 110°C. Under optimal conditions, chloroacetates, chloracetone, benzyl chloride and even some aryl chlorides can be carbonylated to corresponding esters in moderate to excellent yields. Moreover, the effect of Bu4NI on the reaction was discussed in detail and it was critical in both stabilizing the Pd catalytic system and activating the inert CCl bond in the reaction. Keywords Carbonylation CCl bonds activation Ligand-free Pd catalyst Ester 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide is a useful C1 building block for the synthesis of various organic molecules because of its ability to introduce a carbonyl group into the parent molecule [1,2]. Transition metal-catalyzed carbonylation with CO, in particular Pd-catalyzed carbonylation of halocarbons in the presence of an appropriate nucleophile forms the basis for a number of synthetically useful reactions, including the syntheses of carboxylic acids, esters, lactones, amides, lactams, keto esters and keto amides [3]. Among the halocarbons, organic chlorides are particularly attractive starting materials for these transformations, as they are both inexpensive and commercially abundant [4–11]. However, the chemical inertness of the CCl bonds in organic compounds also makes them more challenging substrates. Current developments in the expansion of the organic chlorides carbonylation have been carried out mainly by using different ligands and noticeable advances have been achieved with phosphine-based ligands such as, tertiary phosphines, hemilabile-type phosphines, sterically crowded biphenyl-type phosphines and other electron rich phosphines [4–11]. Although complexes containing such ligands often show excellent activities, in the majority of cases, the principal drawbacks about these systems are the availability, stability, and the cost of the palladium complexes and related ligands [12–18]. From the environmental and economic points of view, the simplest and cheapest Pd catalysts are of course ligand-free systems. Such a ligand-free Pd catalyst system would constitute a significant advancement, especially if generally applicable [15]. For most homogeneous and ligand-free Pd catalyst systems, Pd colloids have often been considered to be responsible for the activity of the catalytic systems [15–18]. Catalytic systems based on Pd colloids are relatively simple and do not require the use of complicated modifying ligands. However, Pd colloids may undergo aggregation during the reaction leading to loss of catalytic activity. Careful selection of the reaction medium, for example, the addition of ammonium salts, may prevent aggregation probably and stabilize the size of metal colloid nanoparticles sufficient for catalysis [19,20]. Recently, ammonium salts stabilized Pd colloids have been effectively used to catalyze various coupling reactions such as Heck [15,18], Suzuki [21], and Sonogashira reactions [22–24], as well as for the hydroxycarbonylation of olefins [25,26] and the carbonylation of aryl iodides [27–29]. However, ligand-free Pd colloids catalyzed carbonylation of organic chlorides has never been reported to date. In this paper, we report a ligand-free Pd catalyst for the alkoxycarbonylation of organic chlorides. Unlike many new methods employing palladium catalysis, successful development of this method did not hinge on a particular precatalyst/ligand combination. Rather, the critical advance was the use of tetrabutylammonium iodide, which acts both as a stabilizer for palladium catalyst and as an activating agent for the inert CCl bond, thereby facilitating the transformations of relatively inactive organic chlorides. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents All reagents, including CH2Cl2, chloroacetates, chloroacetone, benzyl chloride, methanol, aryl chlorides, ethanol, isopropanol, PdCl2, Na2HPO4 and Bu4NI, were analytical grade and used as received. All the solvents were distilled prior to use. Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 was synthesized from the reaction of a solution of PdCl2 in dilute hydrochloric acid and a warm solution of PPh3 (2.03equiv.) in EtOH at 60°C [30]. 2.2 Alkoxycarbonylation of CH2Cl2 The catalytic reactions were carried out in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50mL) that was lined with a magnetic stirrer bar and an automatic temperature controller. In a typical experiment, PdCl2 (0.05mmol), Bu4NI (0.6mmol), Na2HPO4 (6mmol), anisole (3mL) were added into the reactor. After purging three times with CO, the reactor was sealed and placed in an ice water bath. After injecting 0.35g cold CH2Cl2/EtOH (mole ratio 1/2, CH2Cl2 2mmol) solution, the autoclave was pressurized with CO to 1.5MPa and heated at 110°C for 12h. After completion of the reaction, autoclave was cooled by ice water and depressurized to atmospheric pressure. The liquid mixture taken from the autoclave after the reaction was analyzed qualitatively by GC–MS and compared with authentic samples. The analyses were performed in an Agilent 6890/5973 GC–MS apparatus equipped with a split/splitless injection system and a flame ionization detector (FID). The capillary column was an Agilent HP-5MS, 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm. He was used as the carrier gas (1.0mL/min). The quantitative analysis of the reaction mixture was carried out in an Agilent GC 1790 apparatus equipped with a HP-5 (30m×0.32mm×0.25μm) capillary column, a flame ionization detector (FID) with the n-butanol as an internal standard. 2.3 Alkoxycarbonylation of chloroacetates, chloracetone, benzyl chloride and aryl chlorides The catalytic reactions were performed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50mL) that was lined with a magnetic stirrer bar and an automatic temperature controller. Typically, PdCl2 (0.05mmol), Bu4NI (0.6mmol), Na2HPO4 (3mmol), anisole (2mL), organic chloride (2mmol), and EtOH (2.2mmol) were added into the reactor. After purging three times with CO, the autoclave was pressurized with CO to a pressure of 1.5MPa at room temperature. The reaction was performed at 80°C for 3–12h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and depressurized. The liquid mixture taken from the autoclave after the reaction was analyzed quantitatively by GC and qualitatively by GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Alkoxycarbonylation of dichloromethane Considering the economic value of dichloromethane carbonylation [31], herein, we first studied the carbonylation of the unreactive CH2Cl2. Transition metal-catalyzed alkoxycarbonylation of dihalomethane is an appealing method to synthesize the useful dialkyl malonates. However, most of these works focused on the alkoxycarbonylation of CH2I2 [9,32–34], the cheaper CH2Br2 and CH2Cl2, especially the later one, is far less exploited, owing to its much lower reactivity [35,36]. Based on our experience on Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 catalyzed alkoxycarbonylation of chloracetates [37], herein, we initially studied the effect of solvent and promoter on the carbonylation of CH2Cl2 using Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 as a catalyst, and Na2HPO4 as a base. With EtOH as the solvent, no carbonylation product was obtained (Table 1 , entry 1). Interestingly, in the presence of Bu4NI, significant rate enhancement was observed with 15.8% yield of the esters (Table 1, entry 2). Notably, a small amount of CH2ClI was observed by GC–MS. The presence of CH2ClI indicated that halogen-exchange reaction occurred between Bu4NI and CH2Cl2 under the reaction conditions. It also gave us a hint that Bu4NI might be an activating agent for the inert CCl bond via halogen-exchange reaction. To further ascertain this conjecture, Bu4NBr and Bu4NCl were added to promote this reaction. As expected, almost no promotion effect was observed (Table 1, entries 3 and 4). Instead, KI or CuI also showed a little promotion effect (Table 1, entries 5 and 6). The amount of CH2(OEt)2 that was generated as a byproduct from the substitution reaction between CH2Cl2 and EtOH was remarkable (Table 1, entry 2). Indeed, the substitution reaction of chlorinated hydrocarbon compounds could be more-easily performed in EtOH. Switching EtOH for N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) led to an increase in total selectivity for esters (DEM and EA), meanwhile a higher conversion was achieved (Table 1, entry 7). Triethyl orthoformate (TEOF), an excellent solvent in the alkoxycarbonylation of CH2I2 [33], was also tried in our reaction, however, only 20.7% yield of esters was obtained with a poor total selectivity of esters (Table 1, entry 8). To our delight, anisole gave 44.6% selectivity for DEM and 31.3% selectivity for EA; meanwhile the conversion could be up to 66.1% (Table 1, entry 11). The use of 1,4-dioxane gave much higher conversion and a similar total selectivity of esters compared with anisole, but a lower selectivity of the more valuable DEM was gained (Table 1, entries 11 and 12). So we finally chose anisole as the solvent for the next optimization of reaction conditions. With these results in hand, we next tested the effect of base and ligand (Table 2 ). The bases used in this study included K2CO3, K3PO4, K2HPO4, Na2HPO4, NaOAc, Et3N, DBU, DMAP and DABCO, out of which Na2HPO4 gave the best selectivity and activity without the formation of Pd black (Table 2, entries 1–8). This may be attributed to the formation of a weakly alkaline Na2HPO4/NaH2PO4 buffer during the reaction as we mentioned recently [37]. In combination with promoter and proper solvent, this buffer may be able to adjust the rate of oxidative addition and reductive elimination processes, thus providing a suitable chemical environment for the stable existence of active Pd species. It is well known that phosphine ligands can stabilize palladium catalyst and influence its catalytic activity. Therefore, several common and relatively cheap phosphine ligands were tested in this reaction. As shown in Table 2, ligands, such as PBu3, 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino) propane (dppp), 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino) ethane (dppe), gave only low yields of esters (Table 2, entries 11–13). The in situ addition of PPh3 afforded similar yield of the desired product as the pre-prepared Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 (Table 2, entries 9 and 10). It was understood that tetraalkylammonium salts could stabilize nano-sized Pd colloids [17–29], and the carbonylation reaction medium is favorable for the reduction of Pd(II) to Pd(0) due to the presence of potential reducing agents like carbon monoxide and bases. Therefore, tetraalkylammonium salts stabilized Pd colloids might be easily formed in situ in the reaction. With this design idea in mind, ligand-free PdCl2 was tested. To our delight, the ligand-free PdCl2 gave much higher conversion (82.7%) of CH2Cl2 and similar selectivity of esters (Table 2, entry 14). Notably, a clear red solution was obtained without Pd black in this case; it is very important to prevent the formation of Pd black in carbonylation reactions to maintain the catalytic cycle. Also, the use of ligand-free Pd(OAc)2 gave quite similar results (Table 2, entry 15). Next, we tested the effect of Bu4NI/Pd molar ratio on the reaction and the results were depicted in Table 3 (entries 1–7). The reaction hardly occurred in the absence of Bu4NI promoter and almost all of the palladium salt turned into Pd black. However, introducing 4 molar equivalent of Bu4NI into the PdCl2 system, the reaction afforded 23.1% conversion of CH2Cl2 (Table 3, entry 2). Increasing the molar ratio of Bu4NI/Pd from 4 to 12 significantly increased the conversion of CH2Cl2, as well as providing a higher selectivity for esters (Table 3, entries 2–5). Notably, no Pd black after the reaction was observed with the molar ratio of Bu4NI/Pd no less than 8. The presence of excess Bu4NI decreased the selectivity for esters slightly, although afforded a little higher conversion (Table 3, entries 6 and 7). To further determine if Bu4NI is a prerequisite for the success of our carbonylation protocol, we switched Bu4NI for equal amount of Bu4NBr, while the catalytic activity was quite poor (Table 3, entry 8). Meanwhile, the palladium salt turned into Pd black after the reaction. Taking into account the main byproducts were derived from the substitution reaction between EtOH and CH2Cl2 substrate, the effect of EtOH/CH2Cl2 molar ratio was also studied. Lowering the molar ratio of EtOH/CH2Cl2 led to a higher total selectivity of esters, although the conversion rate for CH2Cl2 decreased slightly (Table 3, entries 9 and 10). Notably, by using 2 molar equivalent of EtOH, 67.3% yield of esters was achieved after 12h (Table 3, entry 11). Except for the electro-assisted [Co(CO)3PBu3]− catalytic system reported [36], to the best of our knowledge, this was the highest yield for the carbonylation of CH2Cl2. For comparison, Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 was also tested under optimum conditions, while only 58.3% yield of esters was obtained (Table 3, entry 12). Somewhat unexpectedly, the phosphine-free catalyst showed higher activity than traditional Pd-phosphine systems in this carbonylation reaction. This might be caused by the carbonylation of CH2Cl2 proceeded via the bimetallic pathway [9,32], the bulky phosphine ligand may inhibit the CO coordination and insertion step, thus leading to worse catalytic activity. Indeed, in some carbonylation reactions, the phosphine-free catalyst was also reported to be more active than traditional Pd-phosphine systems [38]. In the following experiments, we studied the effect of Pd loading and CO pressure on the reaction (Table 4 ). Running the reaction at 1.0MPa of CO pressure, a similar selectivity and yield of esters was still obtained (Table 4, entry 1). Further reducing the CO pressure to 0.5MPa, only a low yield of esters was obtained (Table 4, entry 2). Conducting the reaction with 1.0mol% PdCl2, 85.2% conversion of CH2Cl2 was achieved after 20h, accompanied by 62.6% yield of esters and a turnover number (TON) of 62.6 (Table 4, entry 3). Nevertheless, further lowering the amount of the palladium catalyst dramatically deteriorated the reaction rate, resulted in only 49.7% conversion of CH2Cl2, even after a prolonged reaction time 30h. 3.2 Alkoxycarbonylation of chloroacetates, chloracetone, benzyl chloride and aryl chlorides To demonstrate the general applicability of this catalytic system for organic chlorides, the alkoxycarbonylation of chloroacetates, chloracetone, benzyl chloride and aryl chlorides were conducted, respectively. As shown in Table 5 , the ligand-free palladium-catalyzed carbonylation of chloroacetates proceeded smoothly under the optimized conditions, and excellent yields of malonates were achieved (Table 5, entries 1–4). Notably, some mixed-alkyl malonates were also prepared in excellent yields (Table 5, entries 2 and 3). The alcohol substrate did not interfere with this transformation, although a competing transesterification reaction with the chloroacetate substrate or with the malonate product was possible. Acetoacetate is a large-scale commercial product, which was usually obtained by the Claisen condensation of ethyl acetate [39]. Another synthesis method, the alkoxycarbonylation of chloroacetone in the presence of the corresponding alcohols, has also been well documented [10,40–42]. We studied the alkoxycarbonylation of chloroacetone using our PdCl2/Bu4NI catalytic system. To our delight, moderate to excellent yields (72.3–99.2%) of acetoacetates could be obtained (Table 5, entries 5–7). Carbonylative transformation of benzyl chlorides in the presence of various nucleophiles represents a powerful method for the synthesis of a diverse array of phenylacetic acid and benzyl ketone derivatives [43–48]. Herein, the alkoxycarbonylation of benzyl chloride was also conducted. Benzyl chloride with different alcohols gave the desired products in moderate to good yields (Table 5, entries 8–10). Finally, the inactive aryl chlorides were tested. Aryl chlorides bearing strong electron-withdrawing nitro group gave the ester products in moderate yields (Table 5, entries 11–13). Unfortunately, chlorobenzene and 4-chloroanisole gave no target products. 3.3 The role of Bu4NI Based on the effect of additives on this catalytic system reported in Tables 1 and 3, we found that the Bu4NI exhibited a dual role in two fields: firstly, protecting the ligand-free Pd from aggregation as Pd black; and secondly, promoting the oxidative addition step of the catalytic cycle via halogen-exchange reaction. For most ligand-free catalytic systems, Pd colloids have often been considered to be responsible for the activity of the catalytic systems [15,18]. Reetz et al. investigated ammonium salts stabilized Pd colloids in detail, and they proposed that the ammonium salts could prevent undesired agglomeration by forming a monomolecular layer around the Pd colloids [16,18]. In the field of Pd-catalyzed carbonylation reactions, Trzeciak et al. reported the Pd colloids catalyzed carbonylation of aryl iodide [27] and effect of tetraalkylammonium salts (R4NX) on the size of Pd colloids [28,29]. They got further conclusions that R4NX was able to provide electrostatic stabilization of the palladium nanoparticles through the formation of a double electric layer. Similarly, we think that Pd colloids were stabilized by tetraalkylammonium salts in our catalytic system, which served as a catalyst or a reservoir for the actual catalytically active species (Scheme 1 ). These assumptions are in agreement with the experimental results. It is found that without adequate amounts of Bu4NI, palladium (II) reduction to palladium black was easily observed after the reaction; however, the system remained catalytically active in the presence of adequate amounts of Bu4NI. Switching Bu4NI for equal amount of CuI or KI also led to Pd black after the reaction. These results suggested that the carbonylation reaction is in fact catalyzed by a palladium colloid stabilized by Bu4NI. Furthermore, a more-reactive organic iodide can be formed via halogen-exchange reaction between the Bu4NI and the chloride substrate, which was also confirmed by the results of GC–MS. Indeed, we believe that the presence of organic iodide is also very important for the stability of this ligand-free system. On introducing Bu4NBr or Bu4NCl to replace the Bu4NI, the ligand-free PdCl2 gave very poor catalytic activity and Pd black formed after the reaction. This can be explained by the fact that unlike with the organic iodide, oxidative addition of organic chloride is the rate-determining step. A large part of the palladium is now in the form of Pd(0) stored in the palladium clusters. These clusters are relatively unstable and further aggregate to form palladium black when the rate of the oxidative addition step is too slow, thus leading to the termination of the reaction [15]. In the presence of Bu4NI, organic iodide can be formed via halogen-exchange reaction, thus providing much faster speed for the oxidative addition step of the catalytic cycle. The faster reaction rate could lower the Pd(0) concentration and suppress Pd black formation. Indeed, Trzeciak observed that the oxidative addition reaction could decrease the size of Pd colloids in carbonylation of aryl iodide [27,49]. Moreover, the presence of Bu4NI may also make part of the palladium store as bridged [Pd2I6]2− anions [50], which might be favorable for the carbonylation of CH2Cl2 via the bimetallic pathway. Another point to be noted is that quaternary ammonium salts might be carbonylated to amides under carbonylation conditions as we have reported recently [51,52]. In the carbonylation of organic chlorides, we also analyzed the products carefully, no corresponding product for the carbonylation of Bu4NI was observed. This suggested that Bu4NI was stable under our reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the present study reports an active, efficient and ligand-free PdCl2/Bu4NI catalyst for the alkoxycarbonylation of organic chlorides. The best results are realized by using PdCl2 catalyst and proper amount of Bu4NI as a promoter in the reaction. It is found that the Bu4NI acted both as a stabilizer for palladium catalyst and as an activating agent for the inert CCl bond in the compounds via halogen-exchange reaction. We believe that this catalyst system provides an excellent complement to the Pd-catalyzed carbonylation methodology, particularly some active organic chlorides to be carbonylated. Further studies on ligand-free Pd-catalyzed carbonylation of inert aryl chlorides are in progress in our lab.
